newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhs see 14 mln T grain harvest if weather mild.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhs see 14 mln T grain harvest if weather mild.

text.p: Kazakhstan may meet its net grain harvest target of 14 million tonnes if the weather remains mild and farmers succeed in sowing at least 12 million hectares, a grains analyst said on Friday.

"If the weather remains mild with temperatures not rising above their annual average and farmers sow to grains at least 12 million hectares, we may count on a net harvest of some 14 million tonnes," Galina Yergazina, analyst at Kazakhstan's Agro-industrial Exchange, told Reuters.
Sowing on Kazakhstan's vast steppes started around two weeks ago, but Agriculture Ministry officials declined to disclose the size of the total area to be planted this year.
Ministry spokesman Alexander Korablin said over three million hectares had been planted and that the total sown area would be known only in June, when the campaign ends.
"We cannot say what the total area sown to grain will be," he said. "Many farms have started cultivating sunflower or turned to cattle breeding because this is more profitable."
Last year, Kazakhstan was hit by severe drought and gathered a disappointing 13.2 million gross tonnes of grain, or a net 11.6 million tonnes.
But analysts and officials said weather conditions this year were more favourable.
"There is enough moisture in the soil and plants are well prepared for the summer heat," Korablin said.
"The weather may be hot and dryish in eastern Kazakhstan this year, but we don't expect it to be as bad for crops as was last year's drought," Yergazina said.
But farmers face the usual shortages of combine harvesters, fuel and spare parts.
Korablin said agricultural machinery had fallen into disrepair over the past four years and 25 percent of the country's 80,000 combines were unusable.
However large its harvest, Kazakhstan will probably remain a large grain exporter, including to neighbouring Russia.
Yergazina said livestock numbers had fallen steeply and put annual domestic grain consumption at six million tonnes.
"I think official statements that Kazakhstan would export over five million tonnes this year are very realistic," she said.
"Even last year's poor harvest could not undermine grain exports."
